Demographic changes in China have had significant impacts on both the political and economic landscape of the country over the past few decades. The following are some of the changes and their effects:

1. Aging population - The aging population in China has been increasing rapidly due to the one-child policy and increased life expectancy. This has put pressure on the government to provide adequate elderly care and pensions. It has also led to a decrease in the labor force, which could potentially slow down the economy.

2. Rural-urban migration - The migration of people from rural areas to urban areas has increased significantly in recent years. This has put pressure on urban infrastructure and housing, as well as increasing the demand for higher-paying jobs. It has also created a rural-urban divide and has raised concerns over social inequality.

3. Gender imbalance - Due to the one-child policy, many families preferred to have male children, which has led to a significant gender imbalance with more men than women. This has created difficulties for men finding wives and has led to the trafficking of women from other countries. The government has also recognized this as a potential social problem and has introduced policies to encourage families to have more daughters.

4. Education and workforce - China has invested heavily in education and training, leading to a highly skilled workforce. However, the country faces strong competition from other countries in terms of innovation and technology. This has led to the government promoting entrepreneurship and innovation as well as investing in research and development.

Overall, demographic changes have had a profound impact on China's political and economic landscape, and the government has responded by adjusting policies to address these changes.
